description:
Lactobacillus kefiranofaciens is a Gram-positive, rod-shaped, non-spore-forming bacterium that belongs to the Lactobacillaceae family. It is a key microorganism found in kefir, a fermented dairy product. 

Lactobacillus kefiranofaciens is known for its ability to produce kefiran, a water-soluble, exopolysaccharide that contributes to the unique texture and viscosity of kefir. The production of kefiran is a distinctive characteristic of this species, as it helps in the formation of the kefir grains during the fermentation process.

This bacterium is a facultative anaerobe, meaning it can grow in both the presence and absence of oxygen. It is considered a probiotic, as it has been shown to have beneficial effects on human health, such as improving gut health and modulating the immune system.

Lactobacillus kefiranofaciens is commonly isolated from kefir grains and is essential for the production of high-quality kefir. It is a valuable microorganism in the dairy industry and has been the subject of extensive research due to its unique properties and potential health benefits.
